displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. You, you supply pill or do we have to use our insurance? Doctor: We supply the pills. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Um, hum. Doctor: Yeah same with uh the study is to see if a second pill helps this pill work better so if you’re in the group that gets the second pill, we provide that too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there’s nothing for you to do. Family Member: As long, as long as he get – as long as he’s on it? Doctor: Correct. Family Member: And they said he does this three months and then he comes back and get the pills? Healthcare Professional: Um, hum. Family Member: Right.

Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Because they’re not all the same. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so you always fuss about that. Because there’s other people giving high-dose vitamin C Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but you can’t guarantee the product. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Here I’m happy to say the product is definitely of high grade. Uh, but you’ve got to give it two days out of every week. Okay? So logistically that means as long as they are given twenty-four hours apart, you can just come up once, and the study pays for you to stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But that’s weekly. Patient: Okay, well I - Doctor: So like you’ll come up. You’ll get the one day where you get the chemo and the vitamin C. The next day 24 hours later you get vitamin C and you can go home.

Patient: Right… Doctor: Right? Patient: …and after that you guys are supposed to take it over. Doctor: Okay, alright we’ll do that. Patient: I don’t ever see Dr. R____ no more over there. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Every time I go in… Doctor: You just go and get your injection? Patient: Yeah and I think it would be better off do everything here. Doctor: Okay. Well I’m just wondering then if we should hold off and uh because we may have to switch him to Firmagon if he’s not getting enough suppression. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, okay. Doctor: Okay so why don’t you hold off on the injection tomorrow.

Patient: Yeah. You have. Doctor: Because we did it before the testosterone, during the testosterone, during the enzalutamide, and we try to look at how those treatments affect it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I’ll, I’ll find out. Patient: Alright. Doctor: So- Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. So normally what we have to do is go through the insurance company, tell them what we wanted to do, they deny it, you write letters. So it’s not something that I can just do it tomorrow. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well-

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can tell you that the most important thing you can do is not gain weight. You do not need a special diet; you do not need special things. What is important is you don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you stay physically active. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s all that’s important because I mean what is bad is if you get fat, fat is a pro-inflammatory environment and people who do get fat die quicker from cancer. All cancers. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, so, all these diets and things like that, all these special things people offer often at high prices, you know it’s great if you need that discipline, but the reality is don’t gain weight. Stay in shape; you’ll do better. Patient: So like worrying about my sugar intake and - Doctor: Don’t – in or out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: - with this kind of cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We would say forget why are we even bothering to putting you in harm’s way or side effects way – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - by trying to just take care of the prostate when everything else is out there. Patient: Right. Doctor: But given that you don’t have anything else visible and all these years you haven’t had anything evolve. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this is the only area, I am thinking it’s worthwhile considering the cryo procedure. Okay? Patient: The whole thing or is this a partial? Doctor: Well no I think almost all of the prostate will need to be cryoed. So that’s why I figure Dr. C____ should come in and talk to you. Explain the details of the procedure and he’s saying that urinary leakage and everything chances are about one in four after the procedure, but that’s the risk we take and remember we talked about that that you know do we want to take that leakage risk. But given what I’m seeing is it’s that or wait until the prostate gland blocks your urinary flow which is not a good outcome at all. Right, yeah. If that wasn’t such an immediate threat, then I would have said no just sit tight, don’t do anything. Patient: Right.

Patient: So we get the shot right here? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. So how do you like the new trailer? Slowly, then the scans, everything is going to move here. Patient: Really? Doctor: Two years. Patient: Two years? Yeah. Family Member: Are they building a bigger building? Doctor: They are. Okay. That’s fine. Going to expand quite a bit. We were kind of bursting at the seams there so they needed to do it, but it’s going to be on a much bigger scale. Patient: I like coming here better. Doctor: Yes. Definitely. I mean it’s much more in and out, it’s a smaller place, and there are- Patient: It’s hectic down there. Doctor: Yes. Yes. Patient: Tell you? (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. It is a much bigger place. But it needs to be with the hospital and everything.

Family Member: And he’s not walking this time. He has an unsteady gait. He’s stumbling. Doctor: No? Really? Patient: No I ain’t walking the same. Family Member: And I told him he’s a fall risk so I’d like him to take his cane with him. He says well it’s in my truck, but you can fall going from the house to your truck. Doctor: I agree. Better to keep it. Family Member: Period. Doctor: It’s still better than having to use a walker otherwise. So that’s… Family Member: I’m not walking outside with that cane. That’s what you told me last week. And I said alright just go ahead and fall because I’m not coming out to get you. I don’t want to see you hurt that’s why I think preventive measures Doctor: A fracture now would really set us back. So- Family Member: Yes because we have brittle bones. Doctor: And I might put in for a bone strengthening medication just so you know it starts, uh it’s an injection. So if he can get it authorized and all that we might as well start it about every few months we’ll have to do it, so not that often. Family Member: I’m not opposed to that. Anything that will help J___ -

Family Member: Monday, the eleventh. HCP Thank you. Doctor: Okay, you did start physical therapy? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How is that going? Is it inducing more pain? Patient: That’s what I’m thinking it might be from right, right. Doctor: No, sometimes - Family Member: Sometimes, yeah. Doctor: No, my worry is that as we start chemo for the first few weeks of chemo until both of us figure out how you’re going to tolerate, how you’re going to do, maybe back off a little bit and take a break. Family Member: Back off on the - Doctor: And anyway, with the holidays maybe - Family Member: They did give him a set of exercises he can do – Doctor: Okay. Family Member: - at home.

Patient: And will they give me the uh BET thing as part of the clinical trial? Doctor: Yeah, yeah that is part of it. Patient: So I’m in a new clinical trial basically. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And they’ll give me that as part of the clinical trial Doctor: Absolutely Patient: so no out-of-pocket for us? Doctor: Of gosh no that that you cannot get outside of the clinical trial. Patient: Really. Doctor: So you can’t get it if you tried. (Laughs) Patient: It’s so new. Uh and uh do you think within a month or two months we’ll know if it’s working? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah so I’m hoping to get you started within the next two or three weeks. Family Member: Oh yeah I mean we want to start right away.

Patient: But then we ran into,there’s a ballgame. Doctor: I heard there was something going on seventy-five today too. Patient: Middle of that, yes. Doctor: There was some massive drama on seventy-five. Family Member: Oh. Hope we missed it. Patient: No. We ran into it. Doctor: But it was south of here. Something happened south. Patient: Yeah. We ran into it. Doctor: I don’t know what happened. Somebody tried, I don’t know if it was a suicide case or something but they blocked all the lanes or something was going on. Family Member: Yeah. I heard about that earlier today. Doctor: Something was going on so everybody was all discombobulated today. Family Member: It was north and south going into Ohio. Doctor: Yeah. That’s what it was. That was what it was. A little scary.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So new things might pop up. Patient: Okay. And I had some other questions Doctor: Yeah. Patient: about other clinical trial options. Doctor: Oh, yeah, there’s zillions. We are not gonna run out. (& PAT high five each other) Patient: Well yeah, it is. Doctor: I’m not gonna run out, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not gonna run out. The time will just be when your body poops out and it’s not safe for us to continue. It’s just - Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: - stupid to continue. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …is that this is all related to the prostate cancer. So um I don’t think there’s any reason for me to believe or doubt that this is gonna be the prostate cancer. It’s theoretically possible it could be a gist. All right. I think it’s extremely, extremely unlikely. Patient: And how would we know? I knew your recommendation was that since it’s a low level in in the lymph node… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - um that it’s something you wouldn’t biopsy, but um I guess - Doctor: The best way to find out in my opinion – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - is open for discussion is to treat this as if it was a prostate cancer and see if it goes away. Patient: Okay, so - Doctor: And if it does, and in retrospect, because if we give you a hormone therapy, for example and it’s a gist, it will not increase sized at all. Patient: Correct. Doctor: If it’s a hormone therapy and it’s prostate cancer, you know it’s gonna disappear or decrease by ninety percent within the first few months. Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: But we haven’t had a scan since April of last year. So we might as well get one this year. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: See how things are. You know? See how the lymph nodes and bone stuff is doing just to make sure we don’t have to do anything exciting. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You okay with that? So that’s the CAT scan again, there’s the chest, the bone in the pelvis, and then the bone scan, which is basically stuff like that. Just to make sure. Patient: Hum. Hum. Doctor: And we’ll compare it to all the ones before. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: This is not a huge jump. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Nothing that I’m going to freak out about. But we want to be prepared in case it’s starting to wake up. Patient: Hum.

Patient: So you would just give up on the Xtandi and just go with the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: And you know if we were going to do the Xtandi base treatment still then we would have to – I would say we need to combine it with something else and that something else could be the BET1 inhibitor. Patient: Is there a third option you said? Doctor: Well the third option is going to chemotherapy. That is definitely an option. I’m not favoring that right off the bat just now. Okay. Patient: We would do that as a last resort? Doctor: Well yeah. I mean not quite last resort. I’m not sure I want to wait (nervous laughter) Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point.
